results.title: Humphrey Jennings Compilation
results.brief_description: A compilation of works by Humphrey Jennings. “Fires Were Started”: Jenning’s only semi-documentary feature about a waterfront fire service station during the blitz in London. “Listen to Britain”: production of the sights and sounds of people at war, without commentary. “Words for Battle”: spoken. “True story of Lili Marlene”: dramatic reconstruction of the British counter-propaganda campaign against the popular German forces programme from Belgrade Radio.

results.title: Humphrey in the snow
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Here’s Humphrey”.
Join Humphrey on his first visit to the snow where he learns to ski, goes for a ride on a skiddoo, makes a model reindeer with Jodie and plays with snowballs. Humphrey in the snow will delight young children as it is a program filled with fun, games and excitement.

results.title: Human nature (2001)
results.creator_credit: Michel Gondry, Anthony Bregman, Charlie Kaufman, Spike Jonze, Ted Hope, Fineline Features and Studio Canal
results.brief_description: Feature film debut for video filmmaker Michel Gondry and follow-up for writer Charlie Kaufman of “Being John Malkovich” fame. A quirky love triangle about dysfunctional people all wanting acceptance, or is it just sex they are after? Lila (Patricia Arquette) is covered in body hair and loves the solitary life of the wild-outdoors but her sexual needs take her to the city. After some intensive hair removal by an electrolysis expert (Rosie Perez), Lila finds love with scientist Nathan (Tim Robbins) who experiments on mice, teaching them table manners. Together they find a wild man (Rhys Ifans) who was raised by apes, whom Nathan and his lusty French assistant (Miranda Otto) name “Puff”. After Nathan’s taming and re-training of Puff, Lila wants to free Puff from the laboratory allowing him return to his true nature.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michel Gondry, Anthony Bregman, Charlie Kaufman, Spike Jonze, Ted Hope, Fineline Features and Studio Canal

results.title: Human Nature
results.creator_credit: John Bassett and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Planet for the Taking”.
Host, David Suzuki introduces this program with an update on the global environmental crises. Filmed in Botswana, Tanzania, Kenya and the U.S.A, human nature is an exploration of the origins of the human species and the biological inheritance we share with other life forms.

results.title: Human instinct. Ep. 4. Natural born heroes
results.creator_credit: Samantha Starbuck, BBC and TLC Films
results.brief_description: Robert Winston presents this series that looks into what it means to be human: the instincts we have and why we behave the way we do. Humans have a natural instinct to help others, and, by extension, we are programmed to love and protect our children from birth. It all begins with a mother’s drive to protect her young, facilitated by a chemical reaction. The same experience occurs for men. With birth comes the transference of genetic material, especially in animals, and experiments are underway to see whether the same rule applies to humans, who will do more for those that they share the most genes with. The instinct to help others, particularly those who are more vulnerable extends beyond the family, to friends and complete strangers, and examples are provided from a soldier in the Vietnam War and survivors of the World Trade Centre bombing. Wanting to help others is related to our instinct to empathise, a phenomenon that Professor Robert Winston illustrated graphically through scientific experimentation. Our instinct to communicate with others is also covered.

results.title: Human instinct. Ep. 3. The Will to win
results.creator_credit: Nigel Patterson, BBC and TLC Films
results.brief_description: Winning is great and losing feels bad - the desire to succeed can be traced back 3 million years ago where fighting for everything was the only way to survive. The competitive instinct is present in us all, as is the tangible physical response to victory - a natural high. This episode in the “Human instinct” series looks at how we assess potential rivals, when to fight and when to stand back, what makes certain people dominant and how behaviour affects perception. Provides footage of experiments involving small children and behaviour patterns. Also touches on the phenomenon of the fear of failure and the fear of damaging our reputation.

results.title: Human instinct. Ep. 2. Deepest desires
results.creator_credit: Natasha Bondy, BBC and TLC Films
results.brief_description: Robert Winston presents this series that looks into what it means to be human: the instincts we have and why we behave the way we do. This episode in the “Human instinct” series looks at our sexual instinct, why men and women are drawn to each other to have sex and procreate. It looks at the different qualities men and women seek in a partner’s appearance and the role of smell in selecting the right genetic match for future children. Attitudes towards casual sex are also touched on as well as the physical changes that take place when we are attracted to someone. Features interviews with a man who discovered he wasn’t the biological father of his children and the actions of a man who wreaked damage when his jealousy was aroused. Long-term couples speak briefly of why their love has endured. Male sexual jealousy is also discussed.

results.title: Human instinct. Ep. 1. Born to survive
results.creator_credit: Natasha Bondy, BBC and TLC Films
results.brief_description: Robert Winston presents this series that looks into what it means to be human: the instincts we have and why we behave the way we do. Part one looks at the most basic instinct of all, the one that we are born with - to survive the trials of life. The program looks at studies on human babies utilising the only means they have at their disposal, crying. Our universal fear of snakes and the inability to overcome it is also examined, as well as food cravings, the important role of taste as a life saving sense and adrenalin to the fight or flight response - graphically illustrated through a volunteer who ran with the bulls at Pamplona, rigged up with medical equipment to represent his physical reaction. Winston also spends time talking to a woman completing studies on degrees of disgust and how it relates to instinct.

results.title: Human growth
results.brief_description: A mixed group of teenage students in a classroom situation view and discuss an animated film on the subject of human reproduction. By its personal approach, the film overcomes the embarrassment and restraint which is often associated with lectures on sex education.
